00040 /**
00041  * @file
00042  *
00043  * Interface to SRIO
00044  *
00045  * <hr>$Revision: 41586 $<hr>
00046  */
00047 
00048 #ifndef __CVMX_SRIO_H__
00049 #define __CVMX_SRIO_H__
00050 
00051 #ifdef  __cplusplus
00052 /* *INDENT-OFF* */
00053 extern "C" {
00054 /* *INDENT-ON* */
00055 #endif
00056 
00057 /**
00058  * Enumeration of the type of operations that can be performed
00059  * by a mapped write operation.
00060  */
00061 typedef enum {
00062     CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_NWRITE = 0,
00063                         /**< Only create NWrite operations */
00064     CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_NWRITE_RESP = 1,
00065                         /**< Create NWrite with response */
00066     CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_AUTO = 2,
00067                         /**< Intelligently breaks writes into multiple transactions based on alignment */
00068     CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_AUTO_RESP = 3,
00069                         /**< CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_WRITE followed with a response */
00070     CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_MAINTENANCE = 6,
00071                         /**< Create a MAINTENANCE transaction. Use cvmx_srio_config_write32() instead */
00072     CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_PORT = 7
00073                         /**< Port Write? */
00074 } cvmx_srio_write_mode_t;
00075 
00076 /**
00077  * Enumeration of the type of operations that can be performed
00078  * by a mapped read operation.
00079  */
00080 typedef enum {
00081     CVMX_SRIO_READ_MODE_NORMAL = 0,
00082                         /**< Perform a normal read */
00083     CVMX_SRIO_READ_MODE_ATOMIC_SET = 2,
00084                         /**< Atomically sets bits in data on remote device */
00085     CVMX_SRIO_READ_MODE_ATOMIC_CLEAR = 3,
00086                         /**< Atomically clears bits in data on remote device */
00087     CVMX_SRIO_READ_MODE_ATOMIC_INCREMENT = 4,
00088                          /**< Atomically increments data on remote device */
00089     CVMX_SRIO_READ_MODE_ATOMIC_DECREMENT = 5,
00090                          /**< Atomically decrements data on remote device */
00091     CVMX_SRIO_READ_MODE_MAINTENANCE = 6
00092                         /**< Create a MAINTENANCE transaction. Use cvmx_srio_config_read32() instead */
00093 } cvmx_srio_read_mode_t;
00094 
00095 /**
00096  * Initialization flags for SRIO
00097  */
00098 typedef enum {
00099     CVMX_SRIO_INITIALIZE_NORMAL = 0,
00100     CVMX_SRIO_INITIALIZE_DEBUG = 1,
00101 } cvmx_srio_initialize_flags_t;
00102 
00103 /**
00104  * The possible results from a doorbell operation
00105  */
00106 typedef enum cvmx_srio_doorbell_status {
00107     CVMX_SRIO_DOORBELL_DONE,
00108                 /**< The doorbell is complete */
00109     CVMX_SRIO_DOORBELL_NONE,
00110                 /**< There wasn't an outstanding doorbell */
00111     CVMX_SRIO_DOORBELL_BUSY,
00112                 /**< The doorbell is still processing */
00113     CVMX_SRIO_DOORBELL_RETRY,
00114                 /**< The doorbell needs to be retried */
00115     CVMX_SRIO_DOORBELL_ERROR,
00116                 /**< The doorbell failed with an error */
00117     CVMX_SRIO_DOORBELL_TMOUT
00118                 /**< The doorbell failed due to timeout */
00119 } cvmx_srio_doorbell_status_t;
00120 
00121 /**
00122  * This structure represents the SRIO header received from SRIO on
00123  * the top of every received message. This header passes through
00124  * IPD/PIP unmodified.
00125  */
00126 typedef struct cvmx_srio_rx_message_header {
00127     union {
00128         uint64_t u64;
00129         struct {
00130 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
00131             uint64_t prio:2;
00132                  /**< The sRIO prio (priority) field in the
00133                                     first sRIO message segment received for the
00134                                     message. */
00135             uint64_t tt:1;
00136                  /**< When set, indicates that the first sRIO
00137                                     message segment received for the message had
00138                                     16-bit source and destination ID's. When
00139                                     clear, indicates 8-bit ID were present. */
00140             uint64_t dis:1;
00141                  /**< When set, indicates that the destination
00142                                     ID in the first sRIO message segment received
00143                                     for the message matched the 63xx's secondary
00144                                     ID. When clear, indicates that the destination
00145                                     ID in the first sRIO message segment
00146                                     received for the message matched the 63xx's
00147                                     primary ID. Note that the full destination
00148                                     ID in the received sRIO message can be
00149                                     determined via the combination of
00150                                     WORD0[DIS] in the sRIO inbound message
00151                                     header and WORD1[iprt] in the work queue
00152                                     entry created by PIP/IPD. */
00153             uint64_t ssize:4;
00154                  /**< The RIO ssize (standard message packet data
00155                                     size) field used for the message. */
00156             uint64_t sid:16;
00157                   /**< The source ID in the first sRIO message
00158                                     segment received for the message. When TT is
00159                                     clear, the most-significant 8 bits are zero. */
00160             uint64_t xmbox:4;
00161                  /**< The RIO xmbox (recipient mailbox extension)
00162                                     field in the first sRIO message segment
00163                                     received for the message. Always zero for
00164                                     multi-segment messages. */
00165             uint64_t mbox:2;
00166                  /**< The RIO mbox (recipient mailbox) field in
00167                                     the first sRIO message segment received for
00168                                     the message. */
00169             uint64_t letter:2;
00170                  /**< The RIO letter (slot within a mailbox)
00171                                     field in the first sRIO message segment
00172                                     received for the message. */
00173             uint64_t seq:32;
00174                   /**< A sequence number. Whenever the OCTEON
00175                                     63xx sRIO hardware accepts the first sRIO
00176                                     segment of either a message or doorbell, it
00177                                     samples the current value of a counter
00178                                     register and increments the counter
00179                                     register. SEQ is the value sampled for the
00180                                     message. The counter increments once per
00181                                     message/doorbell. SEQ can be used to
00182                                     determine the relative order of
00183                                     packets/doorbells. Note that the SEQ-implied
00184                                     order may differ from the order that the
00185                                     WQE's are received by software for a number
00186                                     of reasons, including the fact that the WQE
00187                                     is not created until the end of the message,
00188                                     while SEQ is sampled when the first segment. */
00189 #else
00190             uint64_t seq:32;
00191             uint64_t letter:2;
00192             uint64_t mbox:2;
00193             uint64_t xmbox:4;
00194             uint64_t sid:16;
00195             uint64_t ssize:4;
00196             uint64_t dis:1;
00197             uint64_t tt:1;
00198             uint64_t prio:2;
00199 #endif
00200         } s;
00201     } word0;
00202     union {
00203         uint64_t u64;
00204         struct {
00205 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
00206             uint64_t r:1;
00207                  /**< When set, WORD1[R]/PKT_INST_HDR[R] selects
00208                                     either RAWFULL or RAWSCHED special PIP
00209                                     instruction form. WORD1[R] may commonly be
00210                                     set so that WORD1[QOS,GRP] will be directly
00211                                     used by the PIP hardware. */
00212             uint64_t reserved_62_58:5;
00213             uint64_t pm:2;
00214                  /**< WORD1[PM]/PKT_INST_HDR[PM] selects the PIP
00215                                     parse mode (uninterpreted, skip-to-L2,
00216                                     skip-to-IP), and chooses between
00217                                     RAWFULL/RAWSCHED when WORD1[R] is set. */
00218             uint64_t reserved_55:1;
00219             uint64_t sl:7;
00220                  /**< WORD1[SL]/PKT_INST_HDR[SL] selects the
00221                                     skip II length. WORD1[SL] may typically be
00222                                     set to 8 (or larger) so that PIP skips this
00223                                     WORD1. */
00224             uint64_t reserved_47_46:2;
00225             uint64_t nqos:1;
00226                  /**< WORD1[NQOS] must not be set when WORD1[R]
00227                                     is clear and PIP interprets WORD1 as a
00228                                     PKT_INST_HDR. When set, WORD1[NQOS]/PKT_INST_HDR[NQOS]
00229                                     prevents PIP from directly using
00230                                     WORD1[QOS]/PKT_INST_HDR[QOS] for the QOS
00231                                     value in the work queue entry created by
00232                                     PIP. WORD1[NQOS] may commonly be clear so
00233                                     that WORD1[QOS] will be directly used by the
00234                                     PIP hardware. PKT_INST_HDR[NQOS] is new to
00235                                     63xx - this functionality did not exist in
00236                                     prior OCTEON's. */
00237             uint64_t ngrp:1;
00238                  /**< WORD1[NGRP] must not be set when WORD1[R]
00239                                     is clear and PIP interprets WORD1 as a
00240                                     PKT_INST_HDR. When set, WORD1[NGRP]/PKT_INST_HDR[NGRP]
00241                                     prevents PIP from directly using
00242                                     WORD1[GRP]/PKT_INST_HDR[GRP] for the GRP
00243                                     value in the work queue entry created by
00244                                     PIP. WORD1[NGRP] may commonly be clear so
00245                                     that WORD1[GRP] will be directly used by the
00246                                     PIP hardware. PKT_INST_HDR[NGRP] is new to
00247                                     63xx - this functionality did not exist in
00248                                     prior OCTEON's. */
00249             uint64_t ntt:1;
00250                  /**< WORD1[NTT] must not be set when WORD1[R]
00251                                     is clear and PIP interprets WORD1 as a
00252                                     PKT_INST_HDR. When set, WORD1[NTT]/PKT_INST_HDR[NTT]
00253                                     prevents PIP from directly using
00254                                     WORD1[TT]/PKT_INST_HDR[TT] for the TT value
00255                                     in the work queue entry created by PIP.
00256                                     PKT_INST_HDR[NTT] is new to 63xx - this
00257                                     functionality did not exist in prior OCTEON's. */
00258             uint64_t ntag:1;
00259                  /**< WORD1[NTAG] must not be set when WORD1[R]
00260                                     is clear and PIP interprets WORD1 as a
00261                                     PKT_INST_HDR. When set, WORD1[NTAG]/PKT_INST_HDR[NTAG]
00262                                     prevents PIP from directly using
00263                                     WORD1[TAG]/PKT_INST_HDR[TAG] for the TAG
00264                                     value in the work queue entry created by PIP.
00265                                     PKT_INST_HDR[NTAG] is new to 63xx - this
00266                                     functionality did not exist in prior OCTEON's. */
00267             uint64_t qos:3;
00268                  /**< Created by the hardware from an entry in a
00269                                     256-entry table. The 8-bit value
00270                                     WORD0[PRIO,TT,DIS,MBOX,LETTER] selects the
00271                                     table entry. When WORD1[R] is set and WORD1[NQOS]
00272                                     is clear, WORD1[QOS] becomes the QOS value
00273                                     in the work queue entry created by PIP. The
00274                                     QOS value in the work queue entry determines
00275                                     the priority that SSO/POW will schedule the
00276                                     work, and can also control how/if the sRIO
00277                                     message gets dropped by PIP/IPD. The 256-entry
00278                                     table is unique to each sRIO core, but
00279                                     shared by the two controllers associated
00280                                     with the sRIO core. */
00281             uint64_t grp:4;
00282                  /**< Created by the hardware from an entry in a
00283                                     256-entry table. The 8-bit value
00284                                     WORD0[PRIO,TT,DIS,MBOX,LETTER] selects the
00285                                     table entry. When WORD1[R] is set and WORD1[NGRP]
00286                                     is clear, WORD1[GRP] becomes the GRP value
00287                                     in the work queue entry created by PIP. The
00288                                     GRP value in the work queue entry can direct
00289                                     the work to particular cores or particular
00290                                     groups of cores. The 256-entry table is
00291                                     unique to each sRIO core, but shared by the
00292                                     two controllers associated with the sRIO core. */
00293             uint64_t rs:1;
00294                  /**< In some configurations, enables the sRIO
00295                                     message to be buffered solely in the work
00296                                     queue entry, and not otherwise in L2/DRAM. */
00297             uint64_t tt:2;
00298                  /**< When WORD1[R] is set and WORD1[NTT] is
00299                                     clear, WORD1[TT]/PKT_INST_HDR[TT] becomes
00300                                     the TT value in the work queue entry created
00301                                     by PIP. The TT and TAG values in the work
00302                                     queue entry determine the scheduling/synchronization
00303                                     constraints for the work (no constraints,
00304                                     tag order, atomic tag order). */
00305             uint64_t tag:32;
00306                   /**< Created by the hardware from a CSR
00307                                     associated with the sRIO inbound message
00308                                     controller. When WORD1[R] is set and WORD1[NTAG]
00309                                     is clear, WORD1[TAG]/PKT_INST_HDR[TAG]
00310                                     becomes the TAG value in the work queue
00311                                     entry created by PIP. The TT and TAG values
00312                                     in the work queue entry determine the
00313                                     scheduling/synchronization constraints for
00314                                     the work (no constraints, tag order, atomic
00315                                     tag order). */
00316 #else
00317             uint64_t tag:32;
00318             uint64_t tt:2;
00319             uint64_t rs:1;
00320             uint64_t grp:4;
00321             uint64_t qos:3;
00322             uint64_t ntag:1;
00323             uint64_t ntt:1;
00324             uint64_t ngrp:1;
00325             uint64_t nqos:1;
00326             uint64_t reserved_47_46:2;
00327             uint64_t sl:7;
00328             uint64_t reserved_55:1;
00329             uint64_t pm:2;
00330             uint64_t reserved_62_58:5;
00331             uint64_t r:1;
00332 #endif
00333         } s;
00334     } word1;
00335 } cvmx_srio_rx_message_header_t;
00336 
00337 /**
00338  * This structure represents the SRIO header required on the front
00339  * of PKO packets destine for SRIO message queues.
00340  */
00341 typedef union cvmx_srio_tx_message_header {
00342     uint64_t u64;
00343     struct {
00344 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
00345         uint64_t prio:2;
00346                 /**< The sRIO prio (priority) field for all
00347                                     segments in the message. */
00348         uint64_t tt:1;
00349                 /**< When set, the sRIO message segments use a
00350                                     16-bit source and destination ID for all the
00351                                     segments in the message. When clear, the
00352                                     message segments use an 8-bit ID. */
00353         uint64_t sis:1;
00354                 /**< When set, the sRIO message segments use the
00355                                     63xx's secondary ID as the source ID. When
00356                                     clear, the sRIO message segments use the
00357                                     primary ID as the source ID. */
00358         uint64_t ssize:4;
00359                 /**< The RIO ssize (standard message segment
00360                                     data size) field used for the message. */
00361         uint64_t did:16;
00362                 /**< The destination ID in the sRIO message
00363                                     segments of the message. When TT is clear,
00364                                     the most-significant 8 bits must be zero. */
00365         uint64_t xmbox:4;
00366                 /**< The RIO xmbox (recipient mailbox extension)
00367                                     field in the sRIO message segment for a
00368                                     single-segment message. Must be zero for
00369                                     multi-segment messages. */
00370         uint64_t mbox:2;
00371                 /**< The RIO mbox (recipient mailbox) field in
00372                                     the sRIO message segments of the message. */
00373         uint64_t letter:2;
00374                 /**< The RIO letter (slot within mailbox) field
00375                                     in the sRIO message segments of the message
00376                                     when LNS is clear. When LNS is set, this
00377                                     LETTER field is not used and must be zero. */
00378         uint64_t reserved_31_2:30;
00379         uint64_t lns:1;
00380                 /**< When set, the outbound message controller
00381                                     will dynamically selects an sRIO letter
00382                                     field for the message (based on LETTER_SP or
00383                                     LETTER_MP - see appendix A), and the LETTER
00384                                     field in this sRIO outbound message
00385                                     descriptor is unused. When clear, the LETTER
00386                                     field in this sRIO outbound message
00387                                     descriptor selects the sRIO letter used for
00388                                     the message. */
00389         uint64_t intr:1;
00390                 /**< When set, the outbound message controller
00391                                     will set an interrupt bit after all sRIO
00392                                     segments of the message receive a message
00393                                     DONE response. If the message transfer has
00394                                     errors, the interrupt bit is not set (but
00395                                     others are). */
00396 #else
00397         uint64_t intr:1;
00398         uint64_t lns:1;
00399         uint64_t reserved_31_2:30;
00400         uint64_t letter:2;
00401         uint64_t mbox:2;
00402         uint64_t xmbox:4;
00403         uint64_t did:16;
00404         uint64_t ssize:4;
00405         uint64_t sis:1;
00406         uint64_t tt:1;
00407         uint64_t prio:2;
00408 #endif
00409     } s;
00410 } cvmx_srio_tx_message_header_t;
00411 
00412 /**
00413  * Reset SRIO to link partner
00414  *
00415  * @param srio_port  SRIO port to initialize
00416  *
00417  * @return Zero on success
00418  */
00419 int cvmx_srio_link_rst(int srio_port);
00420 
00421 /**
00422  * Initialize a SRIO port for use.
00423  *
00424  * @param srio_port SRIO port to initialize
00425  * @param flags     Optional flags
00426  *
00427  * @return Zero on success
00428  */
00429 int cvmx_srio_initialize(int srio_port, cvmx_srio_initialize_flags_t flags);
00430 
00431 /**
00432  * Read 32bits from a Device's config space
00433  *
00434  * @param srio_port SRIO port the device is on
00435  * @param srcid_index
00436  *                  Which SRIO source ID to use. 0 = Primary, 1 = Secondary
00437  * @param destid    RapidIO device ID, or -1 for the local Octeon.
00438  * @param is16bit   Non zero if the transactions should use 16bit device IDs. Zero
00439  *                  if transactions should use 8bit device IDs.
00440  * @param hopcount  Number of hops to the remote device. Use 0 for the local Octeon.
00441  * @param offset    Offset in config space. This must be a multiple of 32 bits.
00442  * @param result    Result of the read. This will be unmodified on failure.
00443  *
00444  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure.
00445  */
00446 int cvmx_srio_config_read32(int srio_port, int srcid_index, int destid, int is16bit, uint8_t hopcount, uint32_t offset, uint32_t * result);
00447 
00448 /**
00449  * Write 32bits to a Device's config space
00450  *
00451  * @param srio_port SRIO port the device is on
00452  * @param srcid_index
00453  *                  Which SRIO source ID to use. 0 = Primary, 1 = Secondary
00454  * @param destid    RapidIO device ID, or -1 for the local Octeon.
00455  * @param is16bit   Non zero if the transactions should use 16bit device IDs. Zero
00456  *                  if transactions should use 8bit device IDs.
00457  * @param hopcount  Number of hops to the remote device. Use 0 for the local Octeon.
00458  * @param offset    Offset in config space. This must be a multiple of 32 bits.
00459  * @param data      Data to write.
00460  *
00461  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure.
00462  */
00463 int cvmx_srio_config_write32(int srio_port, int srcid_index, int destid, int is16bit, uint8_t hopcount, uint32_t offset, uint32_t data);
00464 
00465 /**
00466  * Send a RapidIO doorbell to a remote device
00467  *
00468  * @param srio_port SRIO port the device is on
00469  * @param srcid_index
00470  *                  Which SRIO source ID to use. 0 = Primary, 1 = Secondary
00471  * @param destid    RapidIO device ID.
00472  * @param is16bit   Non zero if the transactions should use 16bit device IDs. Zero
00473  *                  if transactions should use 8bit device IDs.
00474  * @param priority  Doorbell priority (0-3)
00475  * @param data      Data for doorbell.
00476  *
00477  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure.
00478  */
00479 int cvmx_srio_send_doorbell(int srio_port, int srcid_index, int destid, int is16bit, int priority, uint16_t data);
00480 
00481 /**
00482  * Get the status of the last doorbell sent. If the dooorbell
00483  * hardware is done, then the status is cleared to get ready for
00484  * the next doorbell (or retry).
00485  *
00486  * @param srio_port SRIO port to check doorbell on
00487  *
00488  * @return Doorbell status
00489  */
00490 cvmx_srio_doorbell_status_t cvmx_srio_send_doorbell_status(int srio_port);
00491 
00492 /**
00493  * Read a received doorbell and report data about it.
00494  *
00495  * @param srio_port SRIO port to check for the received doorbell
00496  * @param destid_index
00497  *                  Which Octeon destination ID was the doorbell for
00498  * @param sequence_num
00499  *                  Sequence number of doorbell (32bits)
00500  * @param srcid     RapidIO source ID of the doorbell sender
00501  * @param priority  Priority of the doorbell (0-3)
00502  * @param is16bit   Non zero if the transactions should use 16bit device IDs. Zero
00503  *                  if transactions should use 8bit device IDs.
00504  * @param data      Data in the doorbell (16 bits)
00505  *
00506  * @return Doorbell status. Either DONE, NONE, or ERROR.
00507  */
00508 cvmx_srio_doorbell_status_t cvmx_srio_receive_doorbell(int srio_port, int *destid_index, uint32_t * sequence_num, int *srcid, int *priority, int *is16bit, uint16_t * data);
00509 
00510 /**
00511  * Receive a packet from the Soft Packet FIFO (SPF).
00512  *
00513  * @param srio_port SRIO port to read the packet from.
00514  * @param buffer    Buffer to receive the packet.
00515  * @param buffer_length
00516  *                  Length of the buffer in bytes.
00517  *
00518  * @return Returns the length of the packet read. Negative on failure.
00519  *         Zero if no packets are available.
00520  */
00521 int cvmx_srio_receive_spf(int srio_port, void *buffer, int buffer_length);
00522 
00523 /**
00524  * Map a remote device's memory region into Octeon's physical
00525  * address area. The caller can then map this into a core using
00526  * the TLB or XKPHYS.
00527  *
00528  * @param srio_port SRIO port to map the device on
00529  * @param write_op  Type of operation to perform on a write to the device.
00530  *                  Normally should be CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_AUTO.
00531  * @param write_priority
00532  *                  SRIO priority of writes (0-3)
00533  * @param read_op   Type of operation to perform on reads to the device.
00534  *                  Normally should be CVMX_SRIO_READ_MODE_NORMAL.
00535  * @param read_priority
00536  *                  SRIO priority of reads (0-3)
00537  * @param srcid_index
00538  *                  Which SRIO source ID to use. 0 = Primary, 1 = Secondary
00539  * @param destid    RapidIO device ID.
00540  * @param is16bit   Non zero if the transactions should use 16bit device IDs. Zero
00541  *                  if transactions should use 8bit device IDs.
00542  * @param base      Device base address to start the mapping
00543  * @param size      Size of the mapping in bytes
00544  *
00545  * @return Octeon 64bit physical address that accesses the remote device,
00546  *         or zero on failure.
00547  */
00548 uint64_t cvmx_srio_physical_map(int srio_port, cvmx_srio_write_mode_t write_op,
00549                 int write_priority, cvmx_srio_read_mode_t read_op, int read_priority, int srcid_index, int destid, int is16bit, uint64_t base, uint64_t size);
00550 
00551 /**
00552  * Unmap a physical address window created by cvmx_srio_phys_map().
00553  *
00554  * @param physical_address
00555  *               Physical address returned by cvmx_srio_phys_map().
00556  * @param size   Size used on original call.
00557  *
00558  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure.
00559  */
00560 int cvmx_srio_physical_unmap(uint64_t physical_address, uint64_t size);
00561 
00562 /**
00563  * fill out outbound message descriptor
00564  *
00565  * @param buf_ptr     pointer to a buffer pointer. the buffer pointer points
00566  *                    to a chain of buffers that hold an outbound srio packet.
00567  *                    the packet can take the format of (1) a pip/ipd inbound
00568  *                    message or (2) an application-generated outbound message
00569  * @param desc_ptr    pointer to an outbound message descriptor. should be null
00570  *                    if *buf_ptr is in the format (1)
00571  *
00572  * @return           0 on success; negative of failure.
00573  */
00574 int cvmx_srio_omsg_desc(uint64_t port, cvmx_buf_ptr_t * buf_ptr, cvmx_srio_tx_message_header_t * desc_ptr);

00576 extern void cvmx_srio_set_pkind(int srio_link, int index,int pkind);

00578 /**
00579  * Convert an ipd port number to its sRIO link number per SoC model.
00580  *
00581  * @param ipd_port Ipd port number to convert
00582  *
00583  * @return Srio link number
00584  */
00585 extern int cvmx_srio_ipd2srio(int ipd_port);
